Award.AwardTitle: The Emerging Commodity of Restored Streams: Science, Policy, and Econmics in New Markets for Ecosystem Service Commodities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The science and technology of stream restoration has matured alongside market-based strategies for environmental protection, and the two approaches are combined in the emerging stream mitigation banking industry. Stream mitigation banking allows developers to offset stream impacts by purchasing restoration "credits" produced by for-profit companies, essentially creating a market in stream ecosystems. Assuring the quality and quantity of impacted and restored streams, which is required by both market and regulation, is a task of measurement that has drawn scientists into emerging ecosystem markets. More generally, stream mitigation is a manifestation of ecosystem markets in their infancy, such as carbon trading. This research project will examine the application of science, policy, and markets at stream mitigation bank sites by fully leveraging mixed quantitative and qualitative methods. The investigators will combine field and modeling studies of hydrogeomorphic processes; interviews with scientists, regulators, and entrepreneurs; and historical and archival research to fully document and understand the practice of stream mitigation banking. Their ultimate goal is to understand how policy, science, and markets interact to leave a distinct imprint on the landscape. This research will draw on sophisticated theory and methods in very divergent branches of geography and related fields in the geosciences and social sciences to inform a vital environmental policy issue.

This project will shed light on the new paradigm of using markets for environmental management. Theory derived from this project will be scalable and transferable (with appropriate modification) to emerging environmental markets in other locales and other phenomena, such as carbon trading, water quality trading, and endangered species habitat conservation banks. Because the stream mitigation banking industry is relatively young, this project also can inform practical policy and processes. In addition to benefitting researchers and students directly involved in this project, it will help to build the growing community of interdisciplinary scholars through a joint university short-course program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Does using markets to regulate the environment change how we actually regulate the environment? That question is increasingly essential as we consider programs such as carbon markets, water quality trading, or even endangered species habitat trading. We studied one of the most active environmental markets - stream restoration "mitigation" through a unique combination of intensive field work and interviews with those involved in the actaul market. What we found was not only surprising; it was almost the complete opposite of what we expected.

The 'market' is created by the Clean Water Act, which requires land developers who impact streams to purchase stream restoration 'credits'; this is the market. Those stream restoration credits are created by entrepreneurs, but the characteristics of the restored streams are closely monitored by federal and state agencies. We expected that stream designed specifically for this market would be different from those designed for other purposes; for example, some designed for nature reserves or for fisheries enhancement. Instead what we found was that streams designed and restored for the market were indistinguishable from those designed for almost any other purpose.

Our interviews with the actual designers confirmed this result. Almost without exception the designers - mostly engineers - stated that their designs were independent of where the money was going; they had a way of doing things which they would do regardless of the intention, or profit involved in the project. There were some subtle differences between market and non-market streams, but these were over-shadowed by their similarities.

What does this mean? We suspect that it means that when markets are used for environmental management, the regulations behind those markets matter a tremendous amount. Quite simply, the market creates the demand, but the regulations sustain the quality. 

As we consider the use of markets across a wide variety of environmental applications, it remains essential that the regulations underlying those markets remain rigorous.
